newsitem.title: UK: London precious metals push higher, hit resistance.
newsitem.headline: London precious metals push higher, hit resistance.

text.p: Precious metals prices pushed higher on Wednesday afternoon but soon encountered resistance after a firmer opening in New York, dealers said.
Gold was fixed at $327.55 per ounce up from $326.40 this morning and $326.55 on Tuesday afternoon.
At the fix Comex's most active December contract was $2.50 ahead at $332.20 reflecting a firm performance across the complex in Asia and Europe.
The dollar was just under the highs against the mark/yen and Swiss franc posted in Europe and Asia when the U.S. foreign exchange markets opened.
"There was a bit of buying on the New York open from dealers and funds but there was plenty waiting to come in at the resistance," one dealer said.
Resistance between $328 and $330 has held when it has been intermittently tested over the past couple of weeks.

It is established now as the key breakout point spot gold needs to get through before it can progress to the February and April lows of $335.70 where the market's confidence will be seriously examined, according to technical analysts.
"That was also a 63 day moving average. It is going to be a tough number to get across," one analyst said.
Silver's foray was also cut off at the tested resistance in this case at $4.40 where progress has been stopped several times since the market fell below that level on July 8.
"Silver's background is more constructive than gold's but a firmer gold price would be helpful," one dealers said.
Palladium has risen in a near-straight line rise since it dropped from a 17-year peak of $240.00 on June 6 to a low of $162.00 on July 10, and the advance accelerated overnight.
Platinum and palladium held most of their overnight gains made when firmer palladium went limit up due to investor short covering on Tocom.
"It looks like they did not get that resolved in one day. They will try again tomorrow so this is no time to go short," a dealer said.
Funds were also reportedly buyers of palladium in Europe. "They seem to be trying to take on the Russians," one said.
Platinum was indicated at $428.50/$431.50 up $3.50 ands palladium was $$5.00 former at $207./$210.00 having fixed at $209.00 at 1300 GMT, its highest fixing July 11.
The firmer tone in platinum and palladium comes after Russia began shipping to Japan and Europe this month for the first time since 1996.
